choices.text: Displacement is less common than extracapsular fractures
Contour of greater trochanter is normal
Tenderness is mainly present over the anterior joint line

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about intracapsular fracture of femur neck?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malunion is common complication

 

Malunion is not a common complication of intracapsular femur neck fractures. Instead, these fractures more frequently result in complications like non-union and avascular necrosis due to disruption of the femoral head blood supply. Displacement is less common than in extracapsular fractures, the contour of the greater trochanter remains normal, and tenderness is primarily present over the anterior joint line.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Displacement is less common than extracapsular fractures: True, intracapsular fractures tend to be less displaced initially.
 

Option C. Contour of greater trochanter is normal: True, as the fracture occurs inside the capsule, the trochanteric region remains unaffected.
 

Option D. Tenderness is mainly present over the anterior joint line: True, this is the typical site of maximal pain and tenderness in femoral neck fractures.

choices.text: Loss of the biceps reflex
Numbness of the medial 2 fingers

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department after injuring his right shoulder during a basketball game. He was trying to block a shot when his abducted and externally rotated arm was forced backward by an opposing player. The patient immediately felt excruciating pain and fell to the ground holding his right arm. He has no other medical conditions and has never had a similar injury. On examination, there is gross asymmetry of the right shoulder compared to the left, and the right arm is held in slight abduction and external rotation. Distal pulses are full. 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of knee pain. The patient first had soreness in her right knee 4 days ago, after her first gymnastics class. Her mother gave her PCM and massaged her knee, but this did not help. The patient also developed a limp over the past 2 days. She has no chronic medical conditions and does not take daily medications. Height is at the 50th percentile and weight is at the 90th percentile. Temperature is 37.9 °C (100.2 °F). When walking, she limits weight-bearing on her right side. When supine, the right hip is held flexed with the knee pointed laterally. There is limited internal rotation and extension of the right hip. The right knee has full range of motion and there is no tenderness on palpation around the knee. Laboratory evaluation shows leukocyte count of 11,500/mm and C-reactive protein of 8 mg/L (normal: <10). Ultrasound of the hips shows small, bilateral effusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transient synovitis

 

Transient synovitis is the most common cause of acute hip pain and limp in children aged 3–8 years, frequently presenting after minor trauma or viral illness. Key features include sudden onset hip pain, limp, mild fever, limited hip motion (especially internal rotation and extension), normal or slightly elevated inflammatory markers, and ultrasound showing small bilateral hip effusions. The hip is usually held flexed and externally rotated to relieve pain, and the child remains well-appearing overall, with rapid improvement expected with supportive management. These findings all fit the description in this case, distinguishing transient synovitis from more serious or chronic causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis: Usually affects multiple joints, with persistent pain, swelling, and thickened synovium on imaging; systemic features or chronicity are common, and effusion is often more pronounced and persistent. Fever and systemic unwell feeling tend to be more marked than in transient synovitis.

 

Option B. Perthes disease: Presents with chronic limp, reduced range of motion, and radiographic evidence of avascular necrosis of the femoral head, but not acute limp with effusion nor bilateral involvement on ultrasound in an otherwise well child.

 

 

Option C. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis: Seen most often in obese, preteen or teenage boys, with chronic limp and characteristic changes on radiographs (epiphyseal slip); rarely acute, and peak age is higher than in this scenario.

choices.text: Isolated osteoma of floor of mouth

questions.text: Most dangerous type of odontoid fracture as per Anderson and D' Alonzo classification and its respective management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II-screw fixation

 

Type II odontoid fractures are considered the most dangerous type in the Anderson and D'Alonzo classification due to their high risk of non-union and instability. The standard management for these unstable fractures is anterior screw fixation, particularly in younger patients with good bone quality. This approach allows immediate stabilization and preserves most neck rotation by fixing the fracture directly. In elderly or poor surgical candidates, conservative immobilization can be considered, but it has a higher risk of complications and non-union.

 

  • Type I: Rare, often managed with rigid collar immobilization.
  • Type II: Unstable and most prone to non-union; preferred management is anterior screw fixation.
  • Type III: May be managed with halo vest or rigid collar, as healing potential is better.

questions.text: A 7 month old baby boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to “empty scrotum”. On examination, hemiscrotum on right side is not developed and testis is not palpable in the inguinal region. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diagnostic laparoscopy

 

In a 7-month-old infant with non-palpable undescended testis and absent hemiscrotum, diagnostic laparoscopy is the next step. It helps to locate an intra-abdominal or blind-ending testis and plan further management.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. HCG test dose: Used for cryptorchidism but usually at an older age and when testis is palpable.
 

Option C. Reassurance: Not appropriate without confirming the location of the testis in non-palpable cases.
 

Option D. Inguinal exploration: Considered if testis is palpable in the inguinal canal but not detected on laparoscopy.

questions.text: All of the following are susceptible to AVN except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck of talus

 

Avascular necrosis (AVN) commonly occurs in bones or bone segments with tenuous blood supply, such as the proximal pole of the scaphoid, the head of the femur, and the head of the humerus. These regions are at increased risk especially following fractures disrupting their vascularity. In contrast, it is not the neck but the body of the talus that is most susceptible to AVN after neck fractures; the neck itself, if isolated, is rarely the site of AVN—the risk comes from disruption of blood flow to the body of talus when the neck is fractured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal pole of scaphoid: Highly prone to AVN after fracture because of retrograde blood supply and frequent disruption from injury, leading to increased risk of nonunion and collapse.

 

Option C. Head of femur: Classic site for AVN, with high occurrence after femoral neck fractures due to interruption of the retinacular vessels.

 

Option D. Head of humerus: The humeral head can undergo AVN following fractures, especially those involving anatomical neck or with dislocation

questions.text: 37-year-old hospitalized man is evaluated for acute onset of intense periumbilical abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. He has had 2 bowel movements since the pain started. The patient has a history of alcohol and intravenous heroin abuse. He was admitted 4 days ago for fever, chills, and shortness of breath and was diagnosed with acute bacterial endocarditis. His blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus, and an echocardiogram showed vegetations on the mitral valve. He is currently being treated with intravenous vancomycin. On examination, the patient appears in significant distress and is restless. Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min and regular, and respirations are 18/min. Pupils are equal, round, and 3 mm in size. Lungs are clear to auscultation. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is present over the apex. There is no third heart sound. On abdominal palpation mild diffuse tenderness is present. There is no rigidity or rebound. Bowel sounds are decreased. Extremities are warm with normal pulses. There is no tremor. Abdominal x-rays reveal no free air or obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 5-year-old child was brought unconscious. NCCT of the head was performed and shown below. All of the following should be worked up except:

Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

 

The patient’s inability to walk upstairs, along with the pelvic drop on the side opposite to the weight-bearing leg, indicates weakness of the hip abductors (gluteus medius and minimus). This condition occurs due to right superior gluteal nerve palsy, which innervates these muscles. The superior gluteal nerve stabilizes the pelvis during the stance phase of walking; its injury leads to the pelvis dropping down on the unsupported (contralateral) side (positive Trendelenburg sign). When standing on the affected right leg, the pelvis drops on the left side, and when standing on the left leg, the right pelvis rises abnormally.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Left superior gluteal nerve palsy: Would cause left-sided pelvis drop when standing on left leg, not consistent with symptoms.


Option C. Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy: Affects gluteus maximus, leading to weakness in hip extension and difficulty climbing stairs, but not this pelvic drop pattern.


Option D. Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy: Affects left gluteus maximus, with similar hip extension weakness on left side, but no Trendelenburg sign.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis?
A 15-year-old male with pain and swelling gradually increasing over 4 months at the upper end of tibia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brodie abscess

 

Brodie abscess is a form of subacute or chronic osteomyelitis, presenting with gradually increasing pain and swelling without systemic symptoms—a classic pattern in adolescents with tibial metaphyseal lesions. Radiographs typically show a well-defined lytic lesion surrounded by reactive sclerosis, and it most often affects the upper tibial metaphysis. The insidious course makes it distinct from tumors or acute infections, and inflammatory markers are often normal, fitting the described clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoclastoma: Also known as giant cell tumor, typically occurs after skeletal maturity, often around 20–40 years of age, and presents with rapidly progressive pain and swelling; it rarely has such a slow course in adolescents.

 

Option B. Ewing sarcoma: Usually presents with rapid onset of pain, fever, swelling, and possible systemic signs; radiographs show permeative bone destruction and significant periosteal reaction. It is more aggressive than Brodie abscess and often involves the diaphysis, not metaphysis.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Common in adolescents, typically presents with progressive swelling and pain, but radiographically shows aggressive bone formation, a "sunburst" pattern, and soft tissue extension, which is not consistent with a well-circumscribed abscess lesion

questions.text: A middle aged male patient presented with acute onset pain in right limb. An investigation was performed. What is the likely diagnosis?

38-year-old woman comes to the hospital due to right upper quadrant pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the past 12 hours. She has had similar pain previously, usually after the ingestion of fatty foods, but past episodes have always resolved within 1-2 hours. Past medical history includes hypertriglyceridemia, for which she takes fenofibrate. The patient's temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 20/min. Her BMI is 34 kg/m?. Examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Total bilirubin: 0.8 mg/dL

Alkaline phosphatase: 80 U/L

Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT):22 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 4 U/L

Amylase: 81 U/L

Abdominal ultrasound reveals gallstones, a thickened gallbladder wall with edema, and a CBD of 5mm diameter.  In addition to the supportive care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

A newborn baby in the nursery has bilious emesis. He was born at 38 weeks gestation by vaginal delivery to a primigravid 39-year-old woman who received no prenatal care. The patient has voided once but has not yet passed meconium. Physical examination shows a hypotonic neonate with a flat face, prominent tongue, low-set ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. The hands are short with incurved fifth fingers.  The abdomen is soft and without distension, guarding, or rigidity. Auscultation reveals a loud holosystolic murmur most prominent at the left lower sternal border with a precordial thrill. A nasogastric tube is placed, and abdominal x-ray is shown below. In addition to echocardiogram, which of the following is the best next step in this patient?

1-month-old girl is brought to the office for a routine newborn examination. She was born at 39 weeks gestation to a 26-year-old primigravida by caesarean section for breech presentation. The pregnancy and delivery were otherwise uncomplicated, and prenatal ultrasound revealed normal fetal anatomy. The infant is formula fed every 3-4 hours and sleeps 5-6 hours overnight. She received the hepatitis B vaccine at age 5 days. Physical examination shows an alert infant who is moving all extremities equally. There are 4 skin creases along the patient's inner left thigh and 1 on the right thigh. When supine with the knees flexed, the left knee appears to be inferior to the right knee. Skin examination shows a nonblanching, blue-grey macule with indefinite borders over the sacrum. The rest of the examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

6-year-old boy is brought to the office for evaluation of leg pain. The pain has been constant for the last 2 weeks and keeps the patient from playing with his friends. It is worse at night and has made it difficult for the child to fall asleep. He wakes up several times nightly to void and has had episodes of incontinence as the leg pain prevents him from walking to the bathroom. The patient has had no recent fever or dysuria. Temperature is 36.7° C (98 F). Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia; no murmurs are present. A soft, non-fluctuant, tender, 5-cm mass over the right anterior distal thigh without overlying erythema is noted. The right knee has full range of motion, and no effusion is noted. An erythematous, popular rash is present over the chest, trunk, and groin. Hip Xray is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A 22 year old female with primary infertility underwent HSG examination and shown below. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: 4-week proton pump inhibitor trial

questions.text: An 82-year-old man is brought to the hospital with 3 days of fever, productive cough, and shortness of breath. He was admitted to the hospital 2 months ago with right lower lobe pneumonia. His wife reports that he coughs, chokes, and has nasal regurgitation when swallowing liquids or solids. The patient admits the food "gets stuck" in his throat when swallowing. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, ischemic stroke, chronic kidney disease, coronary artery disease, and advanced dementia. His temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg, pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 20/min. Neck examination shows midline trachea without palpable masses. Lung examination shows crackles in the right lower lung field. Abdomen is soft and nontender. Chest imaging reveals right lower lobe pneumonia without additional mass lesions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's dysphagia?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Videofluoroscopic modified barium swallow

questions.text: 68-year-old man comes to the office with a 2-day history of right foot pain and swelling. The pain started acutely when he awoke in the morning. Initially, the patient had pain only on dorsiflexion of the foot, but he progressively developed pain with any movement at the ankle or weight bearing. The patient has not had similar symptoms before. He is normally very active, and had spent a week bicycling in Ladakh 3 weeks prior to this presentation. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidaemia. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min. Examination of the right foot shows warmth, swelling, and tenderness over the dorsal surface of the foot and around the right ankle. Both dorsiflexion and plantar flexion are restricted due to pain. The skin is intact without ulcers or breaks. Pulses are full and equal in both feet, and sensory sensations are normal. X-rays reveal soft tissue swelling, small tibiotalar joint effusion, and chronic calcification of the articular cartilage. There are no fractures or dislocation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

8-year-old boy is brought to the office for evaluation of heel pain. The patient has had increasing pain in the back of his heels for the past 2 months during basketball season. The pain was tolerable until a recent 3-day basketball tournament, which exacerbated his heel pain. He has no pain in other joints and does not recall a specific injury. The patient has no chronic medical conditions and takes no daily medication. Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F). He is at the 98th percentile for height and the 55th percentile for weight. The patient has a normal gait but is unable to stand directly on his heels without pain. Bilateral heels have mild swelling, and the bases of both are tender to palpation. Dorsiflexion of the ankle elicits pain. The Achilles tendon is nontender. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's heel pain?

choices.text: Leg orthotics and physical therapy

questions.text: 15-month-old boy is brought to the office for evaluation of bowed legs . The boy's mother says that his legs have always been slightly bowed , but the bowing appears to have worsened since he started walking a month ago. The patient does not appear to be in pain and is still able to play outside. He eats a varied diet and drinks 300ml of whole milk a day. He is an only child and was born at full term via vaginal delivery with no complications. The patient is at the 40th percentile for height and the 25th percentile for weight. On examination, he has full range of motion of bilateral hips and knee and ankle joints. The legs are of equal length and have no joint effusions. When the boy stands with his feet together, there is a tibiofemoral outward bend that results in a gap between the knees. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

Identify the true statements:

 

  1. Elective opening of hollow viscus-Clean contaminated class
  2. Penetrating injury 6hrs ago-Contaminated
  3. CABG-Class 2
  4. Break in sterile technique-Class 3

A 9 years old child was brought to the hospital after burns. There was involvement of half of anterior chest wall and abdomen towards left side, left arm and left thigh. Calculate the burnt surface area?

Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Miami criteria:  50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
  2. Majority of the retrosternal goitres derive their blood supply from mediastinal vessels
  3. Purulent peritonitis following a perforated diverticulitis is Hinchey grade 3
  4. CECT abdomen in stable patients with eFAST positive is a part of “C” of primary survey

Identify the wrong statement:

  1. Inguinal hernia occurs below and lateral to the pubic tubercle
  2. MEN 2b includes PTH adenoma, megacolon, mucosal neuromas and marfanoid habitus
  3. Exception to Goodsall’s rule in considered when anterior external opening is more than 3cm from the anal margin
  4. Control of active hemorrhage and contamination is a part of Stage 1 of DCS
A patient of RTA was brought to the hospital with left flank bruise associated with hematuria. Patient was hemodynamically stable. Which of the following investigation should be done next?

A 52-year-old female patient present with 4 cm diameter diagnosed breast cancer lesion with ipsilateral axillary and contralateral supraclavicular lymphadenopathy as shown below. As per AJCC system, patient belongs to which stage of breast cancer?

A. Venous ulcer

B. Marjolin ulcer

C. Arterial ulcer

D. Trophic ulcer

A patient complains of persistent, dull, aching pain in both legs. He reports a history of extended periods of standing and mentions having visibly twisted veins in his legs. What tests would typically be conducted to assess saphenofemoral incompetence in this scenario?

1. Brodie Trendelenburg Test

2. Morrissey's test

3. Fegan's test

4. Modified Perthes test

Match the following:

 

  1. Brachial cyst
  2. Dermoid cyst
  3. Sebaceous cyst
  4. Warthin tumor

choices.text: Mixter forceps
Rampley forceps
Babcock forceps

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Rampley forceps

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

  1. Thiersch operation, Altemeier procedure and Delorme operation are performed via the perineal approach
  2. Duct ectasia and Mondors disease are associated with smoking
  3. The boundaries of Triangle of Doom are Vas deferens, Peritoneal Reflection and Iliopubic tract
  4. In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, Signature of the Doctor, Functioning pulse oximeter and Sterility of instruments are components
Identify the renal calculi resistant to Extracorporal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) by their urine crystal:
questions.solution: Ans. C.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut?
questions.solution: Ans. D) All of the above

questions.solution: Ans. C.
